awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Carnegie Mellon University Robotics Institute REU Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site will advance knowledge by training students in the key technological area of robotics and preparing them for graduate study and technical leadership.  The sciences that make up the discipline of robotics provide a unique opportunity to immerse students in research with real-world applications. Rapid research advances place robotics at the forefront of the nation's interests. Furthermore, robotics plays a vital role in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics education due to its multi-disciplinary nature. Robotics-related technologies are becoming ubiquitous, for example sensors and wearable devices, and they are dominating national headlines and discussions on such innovations as driverless cars, big data and data mining, or medical robotics.  An emphasis on increasing the participation of under-represented groups in this site has the potential to extend both the range of research projects within the robotics field and the range of societal concerns and problems addressed by these researchers as they enter upon and conduct their careers. 

This site will provide high-quality guided research experiences for undergraduate students with leading faculty in computer vision, field and space robotics, artificial intelligence, manipulation, and machine learning. Additional mentors, including researchers and graduate students, will provide unique perspectives and insights into science and engineering education careers. Mentors will meet weekly with scholars to facilitate their research experience and positive learning outcomes. The strategic goal of this site is to provide research experiences and mentorship to U.S. citizens and permanent residents from under-represented groups and those from higher education institutions with fewer research opportunities. Student recruitment and selection will be conducted accordingly and will draw on broad past experience in attracting under-served populations.  The leadership team and participating faculty share this commitment and bring expertise in mentoring students from diverse backgrounds to communicate their research results to coming generations of students, middle school and high school teachers, and the general public.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The Carnegie Mellon Robotics NSF REU launches students into graduate school and careers in robotics and STEM fields via mentored research experiences & professional development for undergraduate students with leaders in robotics and artificial intelligence.

Research areas: Intelligent transportation, aerial/ground/marine robots, multi-robot systems, assistive robotics, multi-sensor fusion, big data mining

Unique Features: Broad robotics research portfolio (20+ faculty members), annual RISS Working Papers Journal, research visits with K-12 groups, industry-led workshop, high placement of participants in CMU graduate programs

Research Outcomes:

  • Undergraduate Robotics Research Working Papers Journals (https://riss.ri.cmu.edu/research_showcase/working-papers-journals/) 

  • Undergraduate Robotics Research Posters and Videos (https://riss.ri.cmu.edu/research_showcase/research-posters/)

Breadth & Exposure: The program helps participants understand content by exposing them to the breadth, depth, and stages of robotics research at Carnegie Mellon University by partnering with over 20 labs for tours, tech talks, and demonstrations, and visiting industry and commercial partners.  Annually over 75 professionals shape the participant experience, extend opportunities to explore multiple applications and career paths in robotics, and strengthen learning outcomes. 

Participants Succeed in STEM: The site has empowered many students to pursue futures in robotics. Participants build knowledge, skills, and a network that will open doors for years to come. The site fosters a diverse and inclusive working and learning environment where all students are actively welcomed, included, and supported. We work to create an atmosphere where students can explore and develop their identities as scientists. The site provides workshops and tutoring to empower participants to create strong profiles for graduate school applications and fellowships. Over 95% of participants reported that participation in the program crystallized their interest in pursuing graduate school and careers in STEM.  More than 80% of participants went on to earn graduate degrees in STEM.  Alumni of the program have created a network of support and continue to engage. 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2021
Modified by: John Dolan
